title: Winter Olympics 2026: How Milan Cortina Games will make history with two cauldron lightings at Opening Ceremony
description: For the first time in Olympics history, there will be two cauldrons at the Opening Ceremony.
fullText:
History will be made at the 2026 Milan Cortina Olympics. During the Opening Ceremony Friday, Olympic torches will be used to light two separate cauldrons, the first time that's ever happened in the history of the event.

The lightings, which will take place simultaneously, will occur in two separate locations. One is located in Milan at the Arco della Pace. The second is located in Cortina d‚ÄôAmpezzo in Piazza Dibona. Olympic organizers decided on two cauldrons as a way to show harmony and unity between both host cities of the 2026 Olympics.

The cauldrons are meant to evoke the work of Leonardo da Vinci, particularly his knots, which appeared in his paintings and manuscripts.

While Olympic organizers have not announced the exact time the cauldrons will be lit, it will likely occur near the end of the Opening Ceremony, which will start at 2 p.m. ET and run for roughly three hours. That should result in the cauldrons being lit in the final 30-45 minutes of the Opening Ceremony on Friday.

Olympic organizers tend to keep details about the Opening Ceremony a secret, so there's been no official announcement on who was chosen to light the two Olympic cauldrons Friday.

Typically, the host country chooses current or former Olympic athletes for the honor. At the 2024 Olympics in Paris, French track and field star Marie-Jos√© P√©rec, who won three gold medals during her career, was one of the two people selected to light the cauldron. The other was French judo gold medalist Teddy Riner, who also won three gold medals during his Olympic career.

During the 2022 Olympics in Beijing, skier Zhao Jiawen and cross-country skier Dilnigar Ilhamjan were chosen for the honor. Both athletes took part in the 2022 Olympics, though did not medal in their events.

Italy could turn to skiers Deborah Compagnoni and Alberto Tomba for the honor if it wanted to highlight successful Olympians from the past. Compagnoni and Tomba each won three gold medals at the Winter Olympics during their careers. Neither were selected to carry the torch leading up to the cauldron lightings, so it's possible organizers are saving Compagnoni and Tomba for this moment.

The Milan Cortina Opening Ceremony will take place Friday, Feb. 6, at roughly 2 p.m. ET. It will be 8 p.m. in Italy when the Opening Ceremony kicks off. The entire event is expected to take roughly three hours and will feature a parade of athletes from each country, as well as performances by Mariah Carey, Italian tenor Andrea Bocelli, Chinese pianist Lang Lang and Italian actor Sabrina Impacciatore.

The event will stream live on Peacock at 2 p.m. ET, and will be aired in primetime on NBC at 8 p.m. ET.

title: Carrick stresses significance of Munich air disaster to Man Utd history
description: Michael Carrick said his Manchester United players must "understand the history" of the Munich air disaster as the club prepare to mark the 68th anniversary of the tragedy."As soon as you come (to this club), you're made aware, and you can't help but know and understand the history," said Carrick, who has served United as a player, coach and manager.
fullText:
Michael Carrick said his Manchester United players must "understand the history" of the Munich air disaster as the club prepare to mark the 68th anniversary of the tragedy.

The United team were on their way back from a European Cup win over Red Star Belgrade when their plane crashed in Munich, after a stop to refuel, causing 23 fatalities, including 11 players and staff of the English giants.

Carrick made the comments at Thursday's pre-match press conference ahead of the clash against Tottenham, moved forward a day so as not to coincide with Friday's service at Old Trafford to mark the disaster.

"As soon as you come (to this club), you're made aware, and you can't help but know and understand the history," said Carrick, who has served United as a player, coach and manager.

"I think it's a responsibility that when you work here, you play, you coach, you understand what's come before us, and behaviours and responsibilities that we need to carry through.

"Munich is probably the biggest part of the history of this club in terms of the tragedy itself, how the team and the football club bounced back from it and then went on to success, and everything from there was carried on."

Carrick has had a dream start to his reign with three consecutive wins over Manchester City, Arsenal and Fulham.

The former Middlesbrough boss has the luxury of plenty of time on the training ground with United set to play only 40 games this season -- their lowest number since the 1914/15 campaign.

That has opened up the possibility of arranging money-spinning friendly games, with a trip to Saudi Arabia a reported possibility in the coming months.

No plans are in place for the 13-day break after next week's trip to West Ham.

But there are also gaps in the schedule in March and April that could see United jet off to the Middle East to compensate for some of the lost revenue from not playing in Europe this season.

"We're aware of the schedule and there are spaces, if you like, that we can use in different ways," added Carrick. "So it's all up for discussion at the moment."

title: Key reasons why Davide Frattesi stayed at Inter
description: Despite a lack of consistent playing time and recurring transfer speculation, Davide Frattesi remains at Inter but he is still available for sale.According to La Gazzetta dello Sport, there are four r...
fullText:
Despite a lack of consistent playing time and recurring transfer speculation, Davide Frattesi remains at Inter but he is still available for sale.

According to La Gazzetta dello Sport, there are four reasons why the midfielder has stayed in Milan despite interest from multiple clubs ‚Äì mainly Nottingham Forest.

Chief among them is the club standing firm in their valuation for the midfielder. They constantly wanted a fee of ‚Ç¨30 million. This left many suitors reeling as they were unable to pay the amount.

Secondly, any offers that Inter received were actually far from that valuation. If not that, they only received initial loan deals and Inter were only keen on a permanent sale.

Beyond that, the idea of playing for a relegation-threatened Nottingham Forest never truly appealed to Frattesi. They came closest but they came in as the last resort only.

Besides, the Italian wanted to ply his trade at a high level. On top of that, Inter never really found a replacement, making them keep Frattesi.

fullText:

The professional volleyball player, social media personality and wife of Packers quarterback Jordan Love is one of the digital cover stars for SI Swimsuit's February 2026 digital issue, along with several other NFL wives or fianc√©es. ‚ÄúI always wanted to be on Sports Illustrated ‚Äî never imagined it was going to be pregnant,‚Äù Ronika told SI Swimsuit.

On New Year's Day, the Loves announced on Instagram that they're expecting their first child together, a baby girl. Ronika thinks there's so much power in being a woman and growing a human while still "looking sexy on the beach," she said in SI Swimsuit.

title: Why Eddie Howe must stay at Newcastle ‚Äì and Alexander Isak is to blame for his problems
description: The botched exit of Isak to Liverpool in the summer has had a snowball effect and left some questioning whether the Howe project has run out of road at St James‚Äô Park
fullText:
Newcastle United‚Äôs defence of the Carabao Cup lasted longer than Crystal Palace‚Äôs of the FA Cup. They ended about 20 miles away, but in different worlds: one at Manchester City, the other at Macclesfield. One cup defeat was predictable, the other was among the greatest shocks ever in the competition. Yet if both domestic cups will have different winners this year, the previous pair were different winners.

The historic nature of Newcastle‚Äôs triumph ‚Äì a first piece of major silverware since 1969, a first in domestic football since 1955 ‚Äì prompted the question if it was a stepping stone. The new chief executive David Hopkinson spoke of an ambition to be the top club in the world by 2030.

Newcastle began February 2026 fighting on four fronts. They are out of the Carabao Cup. With an FA Cup tie away at Aston Villa, there is the danger they will be knocked out of that 10 days later. A Champions League trip to Qarabag gives them a gruelling journey, if a chance of progressing. The two legs against the club from Azerbaijan sandwich their next visit to the Etihad Stadium, where the aggregate score in their last 12 games is 40-2. For a side already in the wrong half of the table, faint hopes of a swift return to the Champions League could be extinguished.

All of which could condemn a season to failure. The temptation would be to wonder if the Eddie Howe project has run its course; perhaps he has run out of road as Newcastle struggle on their travels.

There is a theory Howe is given an easy ride, though the audible backing of fans at the Etihad on Wednesday indicated he can still command a constituency of support. Howe‚Äôs achievements, whether twice qualifying for the Champions League or doing something Sir Bobby Robson and Kevin Keegan could not by requiring Newcastle to finally open their trophy cabinet, guarantee him a significance and should afford more leeway.

There was, too, the public backing of his employers, a few hours before kick-off. ‚ÄúEddie's our manager and he's an extraordinary manager,‚Äù said Hopkinson. ‚ÄúWe just talked about how much he's envied by other clubs and the national programme.‚Äù

It is an over-simplification, but if Newcastle‚Äôs problems can be traced to one man, it should be Alexander Isak, not Howe. And if the striker could be a convenient scapegoat, Newcastle are in an ongoing struggle to recover from his departure, the timing of it, and the botched succession.

They made a false start to the season when he was on strike and have been playing catch-up ever since. Newcastle‚Äôs attempt at defiance earned them another ¬£15m, but backfired otherwise. With hindsight, they should have sold when, or soon after, Liverpool bid ¬£110m, not on deadline day.

It may have been an indication of Newcastle‚Äôs place in the pecking order that a succession of other forwards turned them down when at least some ‚Äì Liam Delap and perhaps Benjamin Sesko ‚Äì might have been better off going to St James‚Äô Park. Instead, the Isak fee was swallowed up in the panic-infused prices for Nick Woltemade and Yoane Wissa; it may not be easy to sell either for more than half of his purchase price now.

With an expensive pair of strikers, Howe feels recent results reflect missed chances. Isak, of course, could be clinical. Newcastle only have three away wins in all competitions this season. Last year, he got 12 goals in away matches, plus a famous one at a neutral venue, in Wembley. His pace made Newcastle deadly on the break; Woltemade lacks it, and Newcastle look increasingly confused about how to play with the idiosyncratic German.

Howe can appear confounded by a conundrum. Newcastle are not alone in experiencing complications caused in part by summer spending. It is notable, however, that they operated without a sporting director then. They spent ¬£256m and, so far, they only have one successful signing, in Malick Thiaw. Wissa, Woltemade, Aaron Ramsdale, Jacob Ramsey and Anthony Elanga are not all failures yet but it is a debateable point if any belongs in the strongest side.

Howe‚Äôs previously excellent strike rate in the transfer record, however, should offer optimism. It is significant, too, that some, such as Lewis Hall, Anthony Gordon and Sandro Tonali, were not immediate hits; yet each became integral.

That Italian agents seem to have begun an Isak-esque process to extricate Tonali from Tyneside may depress Newcastle, and indicate they are still not the biggest draw, but also shows some of the issues would remain, whoever was manager.

A reason why Howe has had longevity at first, Bournemouth, and then Newcastle, is that he is in the select breed of managers who can be trusted to help run a club responsibly and who can plot a path out of difficult times.

Now with Newcastle overstretched by injuries, with Gordon hurting his hamstring on Wednesday, with others overworked, with the fixtures piling up and four of Newcastle‚Äôs next five games away, there is the risk it gets worse before it gets better. But the lesson of Howe‚Äôs career, and his time on Tyneside, is that it probably will get better.

title: USA downs Czech Republic 5-1 as Olympic women‚Äôs hockey tournament opens
description: MILAN ‚Äì A team full of star power, the United States women got a balanced attack, including two goals from their 13th forward and a hard-working goal from their fourth line, as the Americans opened the 2026 Olympics with a 5-1 win against the Czech Republic, also known as Team Czechia. In just 6:45 of ice time, Hayley Scamurra scored two goals and fourth-liner Joy Dunne scored her first career Olympic goal as the United States rolled. Czech goalie Kl√°ra Peslarov√° was tested early and often, maki
fullText:
MILAN ‚Äî A team full of star power, the United States women got a balanced attack, including two goals from their 13th forward and a hard-working goal from their fourth line, as the Americans opened the 2026 Olympics with a 5-1 win against the Czech Republic, also known as Team Czechia.

In just 6:45 of ice time, Hayley Scamurra scored two goals and fourth-liner Joy Dunne scored her first career Olympic goal as the United States rolled. Czech goalie Kl√°ra Peslarov√° was tested early and often, making 37 saves on 42 shots, while Aerin Frankel stopped all but one of the 14 shots she faced.

The game was played with U.S. Vice President JD Vance in attendance with his wife and kids, as well as Secretary of State Marco Rubio. Vance stood up and cheered for five American goals scored by Scamurra, Dunne, Alex Carpenter and Hilary Knight.

Carpenter and Tessa Janecke each had two points. Defender Laila Edwards had an assist in her first-ever Olympic hockey game and became the first Black woman to play for the U.S. at an Olympic women‚Äôs hockey tournament.

Czechia next plays Friday against Switzerland, while the Americans are at least scheduled to play Finland on Saturday.

Finland‚Äôs game against Canada on Thursday was postponed until Feb. 12 due to a norovirus outbreak on the Finnish team. Thirteen players were quarantined at the athletes‚Äô village after being either stricken by or exposed to the virus.

USA GM Katie Million said the IOC hasn‚Äôt given direction yet as to whether Saturday‚Äôs game will go on as scheduled, but there is a medical meeting scheduled for Thursday night and they hope more information will be shared.

Heading into Thursday‚Äôs game, only Hockey Hall of Fame forwards Jayna Hefford and Hayley Wickenheiser had scored in five Winter Olympics. We can now add Hilary Knight, who is playing in her fifth and final Olympics, to that list.

Her goal was a beauty as she took Carpenter‚Äôs pass in the neutral zone, lowered her shoulders and outhustled the defender to the net for her first goal of the tournament and to give Team USA a 4-1 lead.

It was Knight‚Äôs 13th goal at the Olympics, which puts her just one off the United States record held by Natalie Darwitz and Katie King. It was also her 28th point ‚Äî four away from Jenny Potter‚Äôs all-time record.

The goal came after coach John Wroblewski tweaked the lines from the United States‚Äô four Rivalry Series wins. He cited chemistry as the big reason he added Hannah Bilka to the top line alongside Carpenter and Knight; all three play together on a line for the PWHL Seattle Torrent. Britta Curl-Salemme was also moved up to the second line with Minnesota Frost teammate Taylor Heise and Abbey Murphy, while Janecke moved from first-line left wing to fourth-line center.

After Wednesday‚Äôs practice, Wroblewski spoke about Joy Dunne and how it was only a matter of time that Dunne scored for Team USA.

To fact check the coach: Dunne has scored in a U.S. jersey, at the 2024 women‚Äôs world championship in Utica, but the point still stands. That it was only a matter of time before she found the back of the net in Milan.

Dunne is a player Wroblewski felt really earned her roster spot on the Olympic team through the little details of her game. She has size (5-foot-11) and incredible compete. She wins puck battles and she‚Äôs strong on the back check.

So even though she hadn‚Äôt scored since 2024, Wroblewski saw her as a valuable player to have on this talented roster ‚Äî and someone to watch.

The goal came off a sweet setup from Janecke ‚Äì the first of two goals in 1:23 as the Americans quickly turned a 1-0 lead into 3-0 to seize control.

Two minutes after taking an interference penalty on Edwards, Czech forward Barbora Jurickova jumped out of the penalty box to score Czechia‚Äôs lone goal of the game.

Jurickova, who started the game as the Czech‚Äôs 13th forward, skated in alone against Frankel with all five American power-play players pushing into the zone. As their time on the advantage expired, Abbey Murphy had a shot blocked and, on a beautiful play, Nat√°lie Ml√Ωnkov√° spotted Jurickova coming out of the box.

This article originally appeared in The Athletic.

title: Notre Dame football set to hire Brian Jean-Mary as LB coach | reports
description: Considered a top-level recruiter, Brian Jean-Mary is a career-long prot√©g√© of former Notre Dame football assistant coach Charlie Strong.
fullText:
SOUTH BEND ‚Äî Brian Jean-Mary got his start as a graduate assistant a quarter century ago at South Carolina for Hall of Fame coach Lou Holtz.

Now the veteran assistant is expected to join Notre Dame football as its linebackers coach, according to Blue and Gold Illustrated. Multiple national reports had linked Jean-Mary to the opening early in the week.

Jean-Mary, 50, reportedly accepted the same position at Georgia Tech in mid-January after spending the past two seasons at Michigan. Jean-Mary never officially joined the Yellow Jackets.

With the Irish, he will replace another former Wolverines linebacker coach, Al Washington, who left Jan. 29 for the NFL‚Äôs Miami Dolphins after four seasons on Marcus Freeman‚Äôs coaching staff. Max Bullough, now co-defensive coordinator at Michigan State, coached Irish linebackers the past three seasons.

Aaron Henry: Notre Dame football expected to hire Illinois defensive coordinator Aaron Henry as defensive backs coach

On Sunday Feb. 1, a source confirmed Notre Dame was expected to hire Illinois defensive coordinator Aaron Henry to coach Irish defensive backs. Former defensive pass game coordinator Mike Mickens left for the NFL‚Äôs Baltimore Ravens on Jan. 25.

Considered a top-level recruiter, Jean-Mary is a career-long prot√©g√© of former Irish assistant coach Charlie Strong. They worked together at South Carolina (2001-02), where Strong ran Holtz‚Äôs defense; and later at all three of Strong‚Äôs head coaching stops: Louisville (2010-13), Texas (2015-16) and South Florida (2017-19).

Jean-Mary was Strong‚Äôs assistant head coach at Louisville and South Carolina and his recruiting coordinator at Texas.

Strong, 65, was recently fired as Tampa Bay Buccaneers defensive line coach after one season.

Jean-Mary, an Apopka, Fla., native who played linebacker at Appalachian State, also served tours at Tennessee (2021-23), Michigan (2020), Georgia Tech (2004-09), North Alabama (2003) and Louisville (2000).

He was defensive run game coordinator most recently at Michigan under disgraced former coach Sherrone Moore. The Wolverines finished third (2024) and tied for 17th (2025) in FBS rushing defense efficiency, according to Pro Football Focus.

Notre Dame was 23rd and eighth in those years, respectively.

Eleven former players for Jean-Mary have been selected in the NFL Draft, including two first-round picks, defensive back Calvin Pryor (2014, Louisville) and defensive end Marcus Smith (2014, Louisville), and six third-rounders: Georgia Tech linebackers Gerris Wilkinson (2005) and Philip Wheeler (2008); Louisville defensive back Johnny Patrick (2011), linebacker Preston Brown (2014) and defensive end Lorenzo Mauldin (2015); Texas linebacker Jordan Hicks (2015).

His most recent draftee was Michigan linebacker Cameron McGrone, a fifth-round pick in 2021.

Mike Berardino covers Notre Dame football for the South Bend Tribune and NDInsider.com. Follow him on social media @MikeBerardino.

This article originally appeared on South Bend Tribune: Notre Dame football set to hire LB coach Brian Jean-Mary, per reports

title: Blue Jays to celebrate inaugural game with dirt cheap hot dog night
description: Do you prefer ketchup or mustard?
fullText:
Blue Jays to celebrate inaugural game with dirt cheap hot dog night originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

To celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Toronto Blue Jays' inaugural game in Major League Baseball, the AL East club will sell $0.77 hot dogs on Tuesday, April 7, at the Rogers Centre.

Loonie Dogs Nights return to the Rogers Centre for a second season after the massive success last year. In 2025, fans in Toronto ate an astounding 826,308 dollar hot dogs. There are several Loongie Dog Night will take place every Tuesday home game in 2026.

Global News reports that Blue Jays fans consumed a record-breaking 92,896 hot dogs on August 26 against the Minnesota Twins.

In their inaugural season, the Blue Jays went 54-107 and had a negative 217 run differential. Still, the organization will celebrate the first game played in franchise history on the heels of a World Series appearance.

A few days ago, the Blue Jays announced that 1993 World Series hero Joe Carter will have a statue revealed outside the Rogers Centre.

There will surely be more competitive baseball in Canada in 2026, and lots of hot dogs consumed.

title: Shedding new light on Clayton Kershaw‚Äôs infamous postseason record
description: Clayton Kershaw often rose to the occasion in the playoffs, a fact that shouldn‚Äôt be overlooked due to his final record
fullText:
Unlike in movies, in real life, the hero doesn‚Äôt always triumph over adversity in the end, and even when he does, it might not happen as neatly as one would have hoped to build the perfect storyline. No matter how you slice it, Clayton Kershaw‚Äôs postseason career has been one of primarily heartbreak, but we mustn‚Äôt let it overshadow its finest moments, of which there were plenty, definitely far more than he gets credit for. Here‚Äôs an intro to a series of articles that‚Äôll break down specific memorable Kershaw performances in the postseason that might not debunk his narrative of woes in October but at least add some perspective to it.

On a very basic level, all those shortcomings became irrelevant the moment Kershaw won his first ring in 2020 might reasonably be pointed out. The future Hall of Famer also later went on to be involved in two other championship teams, with minimal roles ‚Äî injured in 2024, and coming out of the bullpen last season. As fulfilling as those rings likely were, Kershaw, the individual, won them at a different stage in his career. By the time he reached the mountain top for the first time, however impactful and crucial he still was in 2020, the narrative had basically been set in stone, and he was no longer at or particularly near the height of his powers.

Sadly, missing a few postseasons at his prime as the Dodgers as an organization had yet to truly take off, particularly so once the new ownership group really established itself, Kershaw still got plenty of opportunities to be the leading man on a postseason team. Time and time again, those opportunities with rays of hope on different levels ultimately met the same bitter end, oftentimes with the southpaw undone by the lack of support that became pivotal to World Series wins in later years. Certain remarks and a more meticulous evaluation aren‚Äôt the specialty of the common fan, and thus, the simplest explanation is the commonly accepted one ‚Äî Kershaw couldn‚Äôt get it done in the playoffs.

Anyone taking a journey back through those playoff runs of the middle to late 2010s will quickly recognize a second theme emerging right next to that of eventual eliminations. Without fail and with teams that in no way resembled the current powerhouses the Dodgers can routinely send out there for a postseason run, Kershaw found a way to deliver magnificent outings that rank alongside the very best in the 21st century, not just among Dodger starters but all of baseball.

Another overlooked element is one to which Kershaw was one of the pioneers, alongside the likes of Justin Verlander and Max Scherzer, that of prolonged exposure to the postseason setting due to an ever-expanding postseason bracket. Out of the three, Kershaw is easily the one who suffered the most in the playoffs, which is justifiable given that this narrative is in no way built around a house of cards, something we‚Äôve already established. Still, it‚Äôs no wonder all three of these Hall of Fame starters have postseason ERAs significantly over their regular-season numbers.

As was the case with Kershaw and the other two, those numbers overshadow many instances in which these elite pitchers delivered at the highest possible level on the biggest stage against the toughest opponents. Here we‚Äôll comb through some of the greatest Kershaw postseason performances and the context around those games.

title: Pirates sign former World Series champion pitcher
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates are getting some depth for their pitching staff.
fullText:
The Pittsburgh Pirates are adding some depth to their starting pitching rotation.

According to MLB insider Will Salmon, the Pirates are signing former World Series champion Jose Urquidy.

Jos√© Urquidy and the Pittsburgh Pirates are in agreement on a deal, league source tells The Athletic.

‚Äî Will Sammon (@WillSammon) February 5, 2026

Urquidy, 30, began his career in 2019 with the Houston Astros. For the first five years of his career, Urquidy was a valuable depth piece for an Astros team that went to three World Series in four years. His best season came in 2022 when he went 13-8 with a 3.94 ERA in 164.1 innings. In 2023, Urquidy developed an elbow injury that required Tommy John surgery. He last pitched for the Astros on September 29 of that season.

After spending the 2024 season on the sidelines, Erquidy signed with the Detroit Tigers for the 2025 campaign. He only made two appearances for the team, posting a 7.71 ERA. The 30-year-old right-hander has some work to do to get back to where he was, but perhaps a fresh start in Pittsburgh could help him achieve those goals.

BD community, what do you think of the signing of Urquidy? Chime off in the comments section below.

title: Jannik Sinner volunteers at 2026 Winter Olympics after Australian Open
description: Jannik Sinner remained committed to his role as 2026 Winter Olympic volunteer less than a week after competing in the Australian Open.
fullText:
USA TODAY and Yahoo may earn commission from links in this article. Pricing and availability subject to change.

MILAN ‚Äî What does four-time tennis major winner just do after reaching the semifinals of the 2026 Australian Open?

Volunteer at the 2026 Winter Olympics, of course.

Former world No. 1 player Jannik Sinner was spotted as a volunteer for the Olympics of his home country of Italy. In a social media video, he is seen checking tickets for a train alongside Paralympic fencing champion¬†Bebe Vio, who is also from Italy.

ma jannik controllore??? non mi sento beneüò≠üò≠ pic.twitter.com/4mqeCgcfVK

‚Äî sconnessa (@alexiuss11) February 5, 2026

It's proof that Sinner kept his promise, as he was the first official volunteer named for the Milano Cortina Games. He did it as he used to ski when he was younger.

"I am proud to represent the passion for these extraordinary disciplines and the desire to contribute to the success of such a unique event," Sinner said in September 2024.

It's a quick turnaround of jobs for Sinner after he just finished up the Australian Open less than a week before the video surfaced. A two-time winner of the event, he advanced all the way to the semifinals of the event on Jan. 30, where he lost in five sets to Novak Djokovic.

title: Italian reports reveal the truth behind Curtis Jones‚Äô potential Liverpool exit
description: Liverpool contact with Inter Milan over Curtis Jones futureJanuary was supposed to be quiet at Anfield. Instead, Liverpool supporters found themselves squinting at their screens as reports emerged tha...
fullText:
January was supposed to be quiet at Anfield. Instead, Liverpool supporters found themselves squinting at their screens as reports emerged that Curtis Jones, a homegrown midfielder fresh from a title winning campaign, might be available to the right offer. For a club that had just conquered the Premier League under Arne Slot, the idea of trimming depth mid season felt counterintuitive.

Yet the noise refused to go away. Tottenham hovered briefly, even after strengthening elsewhere, but it was Inter Milan who made the running. What followed was a familiar modern transfer tale, one shaped as much by contracts and leverage as by footballing logic.

From Italy came word of a proposal built around caution. Inter Milan were said to be keen on a six month loan for Jones, with an option to turn that temporary stay into something permanent in the summer. On the surface it suited Inter, who would assess the fit before committing, and it offered Liverpool flexibility.

On Merseyside, however, the mood was more guarded. With the squad already tested by injuries, there was little appetite for further disruption. Liverpool based reporters suggested the club had drawn a line, no more exits, no more risk.

Italian reporting told a subtly different story, one that placed Liverpool at the centre of the opening move.

‚ÄúThere was also the possibility of a surprise signing, namely Jones from Liverpool,‚Äù the report reads.

‚ÄúIt was the Reds themselves who proposed the deal (on loan) to Inter, who promptly reached an agreement with the player.

‚ÄúHowever, the English club themselves backed out: the contract expiring in 2027 was a complication, but the fear of weakening the squad also played a role.‚Äù

That line about 2027 matters. Curtis Jones has two seasons left on his deal, a timeline that sharpens every conversation. A loan without an extension would have brought him back with just one year remaining, a scenario that rarely strengthens a selling position.

From Liverpool‚Äôs perspective, extending first would have protected value. From Jones‚Äô side, committing to a short term renewal without clarity on his role or salary was less appealing. The stand off was predictable, if uncomfortable.

Jones signed his last contract in 2022, when he was still fighting for minutes. Since then he has grown into a reliable contributor, particularly during the title run, and his performances this season have carried added weight in a demanding campaign. Wanting improved terms feels reasonable, even inevitable.

So where does this leave Liverpool, Curtis Jones and Inter Milan? History offers a warning. Allowing assets to drift towards the end of contracts has proved costly before, and there is little chance the club will repeat that mistake.

Jones will not be allowed to stroll into 2027 uncommitted. Either a new agreement is found, or Liverpool will test the market again, perhaps with Inter Milan or another suitor waiting. For now, the midfielder remains where he started, valued, wanted, but unresolved, a reminder that even champions spend plenty of time negotiating with the future.

title: Super Bowl Anytime Touchdown Scorer: Picks, Odds & Strategy
description: Get expert Super Bowl anytime touchdown scorer predictions, odds, strategy, and top player picks for Super Bowl 60. Learn how to bet smarter on this popular NFL prop.
fullText:
As the Seattle Seahawks and New England Patriots prepare for a high-stakes Super Bowl rematch at Levi‚Äôs Stadium, anytime touchdown props remain the most electric way to get skin in the game.

Whether you‚Äôre banking on Kenneth Walker III to exploit a gap in the New England front or expecting Drake Maye to call his own number on a red-zone scramble, the¬†anytime TD market allows you to turn every trip inside the 20 into a potential celebration.

Join us as we delve into this popular Super Bowl props market with odds, Super Bowl picks, and insightful TD trends.

Bettors have been banking big on Kenneth Walker III, who leads all players with four postseason touchdowns. That includes a sizzling three TD performance against the 49ers in which he ran for 116 yards on 19 carries.

The bruising back should continue to carry the load for the Seahawks, who will be without Zach Charbonnet, who sustained a season-ending ACL injury against San Francisco.

Looking for extra value? Drake Maye's anytime TD odds have been boosted to +350 by our friends at BET99. You won't find a better price on this market in Canada.

Rhamondre Stevenson hasn't scored in the postseason yet, but he finished the regular season with at least one TD in three straight games, crossing the goal line a collective six times in those outings. Expect the Pats' RB1 to scamper into the end zone again on Sunday.

Rashid Shaheed is a home run threat and faces a man-heavy scheme from the Patriots, which also him to utilize his speed and seperation. Seattle is also using the WR in the running game with tricky handoffs. He has options on how to get inside the end zone.

Read more of Jason's¬†Super Bowl LX predictions and picks before game time.

Mack Hollins has been in and out of the lineup with injuries, but he logged more snaps during the AFC Conference Championship than any other¬†New England Patriots¬†wide receiver, signaling clear trust when he‚Äôs healthy.¬†It‚Äôs a steep price, but one that makes sense for a receiver who should be competing for the team lead in targets.

Not only is Drake Maye the¬†only Patriot¬†to score a rushing touchdown this postseason, but he's already logged 141 rushing yards on 24 carries against three elite defenses, including two games with double-digit attempts. Don't be surprised to see him call his own number when it matters most.

Elijah Arroyo is Josh's longshot Super Bowl TD pick. Although not a primary option, the Seahawks tight end is expected to see around 40% of the snaps and run roughly 30% of the routes.

Read Josh's Super Bowl touchdown prop picks for even more analysis.

Josh expects Stevenson to get all the work to the red zone, but Maye will take the ball over the threshold as the Seahawks have allowed just five RB rushing TDs this year. Shaheed, meanwhile, has breakaway speed and can contribute on both special teams and on offense, while Hollins' price is too long to not add for a +8500 monster moonshot.

Read more of Josh's insights in his¬†Seahawks vs. Patriots Predictions, Picks & Best Bets.

An anytime touchdown bet involves wagering on whether a specific player will score a touchdown at any point during the game, not just the first TD.

For example, if you bet on Patriots running back Rhamondre Stevenson to score an anytime touchdown and he finds the end zone at any time during the Super Bowl, you win the bet.

This type of bet is popular because it allows for more scoring opportunities, and you can often choose players based on advantageous matchups. The odds can vary based on the player‚Äôs scoring potential and the strength of the team‚Äôs offensive scheme.

Here are some of the key factors oddsmakers consider when setting touchdown prop odds:

Player performance: Historical data on a player's scoring ability, including past touchdowns, carries, and target share, is crucial.

Matchup analysis: The opposing defense's strengths and weaknesses are evaluated, including how well they defend against specific positions.

Injury reports: Injuries to key players can impact a player's likelihood of scoring. Check out our NFL Injuries page to stay up to date before making your wager.

Game script: Oddsmakers consider potential game scenarios, such as whether a team is expected to be ahead or behind and how that may impact their strategy.

Public sentiment: Betting patterns and public perception can also sway odds. If a player is very popular or a big favorite, sportsbooks may adjust their odds to mitigate risk. You can check out our Covers NFL picks consensus to see how the public is leaning.

The Super Bowl has evolved into a pass-heavy spectacle, as seen in Super Bowl 59, where five of the seven total touchdowns were caught by wide receivers.

The table below tracks every anytime touchdown over the last decade of Super Bowls from Super Bowl 50 to Super Bowl 59.

WRs have scored 50% of all TDs in the last 3 Super Bowls.

Often all or nothing. Saquon Barkley had 25 carries but 0 TDs in SB 59.

Travis Kelce has been the standard, but SB 59 saw a TE shutout.

Jalen Hurts holds the record with 4 career SB rushing TDs.

Cooper DeJean‚Äôs pick-6 in 2025 was the first since Super Bowl 50.

title: 26 fun facts to know for Super Bowl 60: A quick guide to Patriots vs. Seahawks rematch in 2026
description: Don't have a good read on the biggest storylines for the surprise Super Bowl 60 with New England and Seattle meeting in the big game for the first time in 11 years? Here's a rapid-fire way to become an instant expert.
fullText:
26 fun facts to know for Super Bowl 60: A quick guide to Patriots vs. Seahawks rematch in 2026 originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Welcome to the two-week build-up for Super Bowl 60.

While there will be plenty of ways to break down the epic game matchup between the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks, including in-depth picks and predictions from Sporting News, there are plenty of fun, fast facts you need to know before having a proper casual conversation about the game.

If you're looking to absorb some cool information about the game, the quarterbacks, the coaches and other players, you've come to the right place. This handy-dandy easy-read guide will make you an instant expert on some of the Super Bowl history at stake well before the Patriots and Seahawks take the field the following Sunday, Feb. 8 (6:30 p.m. ET, NBC/Peacock) at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif.:

Who will win Super Bowl 60 between Patriots and Seahawks?

Seahawks open as favorites over Patriots for Super Bowl 60

Mandatory Credit: Mark J. Rebilas-USA TODAY Sports

The Seahawks and Patriots are the latest of 10 Super Bowl team rematches. The Seahawks and Patriots played a 27-24 thriller in Super Bowl 49 in Arizona, with the Patriots denying the Seahawks a repeat ring. The Steelers-Cowboys have met in a record three Super Bowls. The other previous repeats are Dolphins-Washington, 49ers-Bengals, Cowboys-Bills, Patriots-Giants, Patriots-Eagles, Patriots-Rams, Chiefs-49ers and Chiefs-Eagles.

The Seahawks and Patriots are still a very fresh Super Bowl matchup. Neither team has players left on rosters from Super Bowl 49 11 seasons ago. This is also the first time that neither coach-starting quarterback combination for both teams ‚Äî Patriots' Mike Vrabel and Drake Maye nor the Seahawks' Mike Macdonald and Sam Darnold ‚Äî since Super Bowl 47, with it was the Ravens (John Harbaugh-Joe Flacco) beating the 49ers (Jim Harbaugh-Colin Kaepernick) in Super Bowl 47.

The Patriots are better at winning odd-numbered Super Bowls than even ones. The Patriots can't love playing in Super Bowl 60, given they lost 20, 42, 46, 52. They are 2-4 when the Super Bowl is even coming off an odd regular season. They are 4-1 in previous odd Super Bowls, only losing 31 to the Packers but winning 39, 49, 51, 53. The Seahawks are hoping things will "even" out and they can improve to 1-1 against the Patriots in Super Bowls.

This is the third Super Bowl the 49ers have hosted. Their current home of Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif., also hosted the Broncos' win over the Panthers in Super Bowl 50, Peyton Manning's last NFL game. But the Bay Area also hosted Super Bowl 19, when Joe Montana led the 49ers over the Dolphins to victory at Stanford Stadium.

California will be hosting its 14th Super Bowl. Other than the Bay Area's trio, Los Angeles, San Diego, Pasadena and Inglewood have hosted a combined 11 Super Bowls out of 60. Super Bowl 61 will make that number 15, with the Rams and Chargers hosting only five years after the Rams won Super Bowl 56 at SoFi Stadium.

Where is Super Bowl 60 located?

What to know about Super Bowl 60 halftime show performance

This is Sam Darnold's second Super Bowl. If you're keeping score, it would be Darnold 2, and the rest of the vaunted 2018 quarterback draft class ‚Äî Baker Mayfield, Josh Allen and Lamar Jackson 0. Darnold was the backup to Brock Purdy during the 49ers' overtime loss to the Chiefs in Super Bowl 58.

This is Drake Maye's second Super Bowl, too. If you count going as a fan at 13 years old to see his Charlotte hometown Carolina Panthers play the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl 50, then the answer would be yes. That game was also played in Levi's Stadium.

Darnold is 0-4 against the Patriots. That includes three times seeing ghosts as a Jets No. 3 overall draft pick in his three seasons with New York. He also went 0-1 facing the Patriots as the Panthers' starting QB in 2021. He lost to Tom Brady twice and then Cam Newton and Mac Jones once each, so this is his first time dueling Maye.

Darnold's passing numbers are terrible combined when facing New England's defense: a TD to 9 interceptions, 52.0 completion percentage, 9 sacks, 5.4 yards per attempt, and a 41.2 rating. He is a much different QB, however, in the last two seasons with Minnesota and Seattle.

Drake Maye is the second-youngest QB to start a Super Bowl. Dan Marino, who led the Dolphins to Super Bowl 19 vs. the 49ers as NFL MVP in 1984, was 23 years and 127 days old. Maye is next now, set for 23 years and 162 days old. Now Maye is trying to beat out Ben Roethlisberger, 23 years and 340 days old in Super Bowl 40, as the youngest starting QB to win the Super Bowl. Brady and Patrick Mahomes didn't win their first Super Bowls until they were 24.

Inside Super Bowl 60 broadcast team on NBC

Maye (2024) and Darnold ('19) were both No. 3 overall picks in their drafts. They are the first QBs drafted in that spot to play in a Super Bowl since Falcons league MVP Matt Ryan, who lost in Super Bowl 51 when Brady and the Patriots made their epic comeback from 28-3 down.

Maye is trying to become the fifth second-year starting QB to win a Super Bowl. In order since 1999, the four who did it before were Kurt Warner, Brady, Roethlisberger and Russell Wilson. Wilson did it most recently for the Seahawks in Super Bowl 48.

Darnold is trying to become the second eighth-year starting QB to win a Super Bowl. The other was the Giants' Eli Manning, who won his second ring with the Giants after the 2011 season.

Maye and Darnold can both thank Josh McCown for helping them develop into Super Bowl quarterbacks. Maye, in his 2019 junior year at Myers Park High School in Charlotte, had McCown as his quarterbacks coach. Darnold was backed up by McCown during his 2018 rookie season with the Jets. McCown became the quarterbacks coach of the Vikings in 2024 and was.a big reason Darnold landed in Minnesota to have his delayed breakout season.

Maye (North Carolina) and Darnold (Southern California) are the first QBs to start a Super Bowl from their respective colleges. Maye is the first from UNC, the alma mater of Giants Super Bowl legend Lawrence Taylor. Darnold is the first from USC, who have four Super Bowl rings each from Ronnie Lott and Lynn Swann.

Sporting News expert predictions for Super Bowl 60

Super Bowl 60 picks against the spread

Mike Macdonald worked longest for John Harbaugh but also had one season with Jim Harbaugh. From coaching intern in 2014 to defensive coordinator in 2022-'23, McDonald spent nine spread-out seasons with the Ravens under John before becoming the Seahawkss' head coach in 2024. Macdonald was Jim's defensive coordinator at Michigan in 2021, three seasons before they won with Jesse Minnter at DC in '24. Minter replaced John as the Ravens' head coach in '26.

Klint Kubiak is trying to win a Super Bowl as an offensive coordinator where his dad won as a head coach. Gary Kubiak led the Broncos to Super Bowl 50 victory over the Panthers 10 years ago at Levi's Stadium. His brother Klay Kubiak is looking for his first ring as 49ers' offensive coordinator, while his other brother Klein works as a Cowboys' personnel scout.

Josh McDaniels is going for his seventh Super Bowl ring. McDaniels was an offensive assistant for Bill Belichick from 2001-2005 for his first three Patriots Super Bowl victories. He was Brady's offensive coordinator for the second trio of Patriots' rings, including the most recent win, over the Rams in Super Bowl 53. Now he can be the most decorated Patriot, other than owner Robert Kraft.

Mike Vrabel is trying to win his fourth Super Bowl ring. Vrabel won his three Super Bowls in the first half of the Patriots' dynasty with Brady and Belichick, serving as star linebacker and occasional red zone tight end.

Mike Vrabel would be the first person to win a Super Bowl as a player and coach for the same team. Mike Ditka, Tom Flores, Tony Dungy, and Doug Pederson all have won Super Bowls as players and coaches, but did it for two teams. Vrabel can make history by leading his former team to victory. John Elway is the only person to win a Super Bowl with his team as a player and general manager.

Why Seahawks' bold move to sign Sam Darnold paid off with return to Super Bowl

3 reasons Patriots defense can dominate in Super Bowl 60

Jaxon Smith-Njigba and Sam Darnold are trying for the rare Rose Bowl and Super Bowl MVP double. Only the Raiders and Stanford legend Jim Plunkett has pulled that off in both Pasadena and the Super Bowl. Christian McCaffrey fell just short of winning a Super Bowl with the 49ers, while Drew Brees would have done it had Purdue not to lost to Washington in his Rose Bowl.

Smith-Njigba is trying to become the NFL's fifth reigning regular-season receiving yards leader to win the Super Bowl. The last to do this was JSN's teammate with the Rams, Cooper Kupp, after the 2021 season in Super Bowl 56. Before then, it was 49ers GOAT Jerry Rice twice and Cowboys Hall of Famer Drew Pearson once.

Kupp is trying to join the club of players to win Super Bowls with multiple teams. There have been 34 offensive players to win the Super Bowl with at least two teams and 64 overall, the latest being former Patriots and Chiefs guard Joe Thuney. The other wide receivers to do it are Billy Davis, Ed McCaffrey, Marcus Nash, Ricky Proehl and Torrey Smith. Linebacker Matt Millen is the only player to win Super Bowls with three teams.

Kupp is only one of four Seahawks with previous Super Bowl experience. Darnold and linebacker Ernest Jones, Kupp's fellow former Rams teammate, are two of the others. New running back Cam Akers rounds out the list, who was injured during the Rams' winning Super Bowl 56 run.

Milton Williams is trying to win the Super Bowl with two teams in two years. He won a ring as an Eagles defensive tackle in Super Bowl 59 and is trying to do it as a Patriot in Super Bowl 60.¬† Only eight previous players have done this: Ken Norton Jr., Deion Sanders, Brandon Browner, Derrick Martin, Chris Long, LeGarrette Blount, LeSean McCoy and Kendall Blanton. Long and Blount went from winning Super Bowl 51 with the Patriots to winning Super Bowl 52 with the Eagles. Williams is going for the flip-flop of that accomplishment.

The Patriots have five players with previous Super Bowl experience. Williams won Super Bowl 59 with the Eagles, while Hollins joined Long and Blount on the Super Bowl 52 champions. Cornerback Carlton Davis won Super Bowl 55 with the Buccaneers. Linebacker Christian Ellis was on the Eagles team that lost Super Bowl 56. Hooper was a tight end for Ryan when the Falcons lost to the Patriots in Super 51.

Stefon Diggs is making his first Super Bowl after 80 career playoff receptions. He is No. 12 all-time in that category. Everyone ahead of him has played in a Super Bowl, with the exception of the Rams' Davante Adams (83 catches, No. 11), whose team lost to the Seahawks in the NFC championship game. Eight of the top 10 players ahead of both receivers have won Super Bowls, with Wes Welker (7th) and Andre Reed (10th) being the two exceptions.

title: Tarik Skubal arbitration, future after Tigers' Framber Valdez signing
description: How does the Framber Valdez signing impact the Detroit Tigers' plans for Tarik Skubal in 2026, and the pursuit of a World Series ring?
fullText:
It has been a busy past few days for the Detroit Tigers.

They made a surprising move Wednesday night in MLB free agency, signing lefty starter Framber Valdez to a three-year, $115 million deal. The move gives the Tigers the best chance to win the American League Central Division (per FanGraphs), and pairs a top-end starter with the two-time, reigning AL Cy Young Award winner Tarik Skubal.

Speaking of Skubal, he had his arbitration hearing earlier Wednesday. We await the final ruling, but it may determine whether the Tigers can continue adding to their roster a few weeks before the Tigers' spring training exhibition schedule begins.

Here's a quick rundown of Detroit's busy week, how much the Tigers have improved and where they can go in the future.

MORE: Does Tigers' big swing on Framber Valdez change narrative about team?

Unless the Tigers make another unexpected move in signing their ace to a long-term deal, Skubal will be making less money than Valdez in 2026. How much less is still a mystery, however.

The Tigers and Skubal underwent a salary arbitration hearing yesterday, with a three-person panel's decision on Skubal's 2026 salary expected to be released today.

Players entering their fourth year of MLB service are eligible for salary arbitration if he and his team cannot agree on a contract for the upcoming season. Through arbitration, the team and player each submit a salary they believe the player should be paid, and a three-person panel (generally made up of legal professionals who work outside of baseball) decides whether the player is worth more or less than the midway point of each filing.

[ MUST LISTEN:¬†Make¬†"Days of Roar"¬†your go-to Tigers¬†podcast, available anywhere you listen to podcasts (Apple,¬†Spotify)¬†]

Sound complicated? Let's use an example Tigers fans are paying close attention to.

The Tigers submitted a $19 million salary in Skubal's arbitration, while Skubal filed at $32 million. That means that if the panel decides Skubal is worth more than $25.5 million in 2026 (the midway point of each filing), he will win his case and earn an arbitration record-breaking $32 million salary. Conversely, if the panel decides Skubal is worth less than $25.5 million for the upcoming season, the Tigers will win the case and pay Skubal $19 million.

The Tigers and Skubal can still agree to a long-term deal following the arbitration decision, but the likelihood of that happening is low with Skubal's agent Scott Boras traditionally taking his clients to free agency instead of signing long-term deals beforehand.

No matter how the decision shakes out, however, Skubal's salary in 2026 will fall below Valdez's $38.3 million in average annual value (with Skubal likely eclipsing that figure when he signs a long-term deal of his own).

There has been some speculation that Valdez is a top-of-the-rotation replacement for Skubal, but The Athletic's Ken Rosenthal has already reported that the Tigers plan on keeping Skubal for 2026 in a win-now move.

"One rival executive, granted anonymity for his candor, speculated Wednesday night that a potential trade partner for the Tigers might want to see what Skubal gets in arbitration before finalizing its proposed blockbuster. But really, what are we talking about? If the Tigers traded Skubal¬†after¬†signing Valdez, their fans would be perfectly justified marching on Comerica Park in a massive protest," he wrote.

That means that Tigers fans can breathe easily, for now, and look forward to Skubal and Valdez at the top of the rotation for 2026. Whether Skubal returns to the Tigers in 2027, however, is still yet to be determined.

Before Wednesday, the Tigers had made few notable offseason transactions in comparison to AL rivals like the Toronto Blue Jays and Boston Red Sox, whose odds to win the AL pennant are currently higher than those of the Tigers per BetMGM. The Tigers also entered the offseason with an urgent need to improve with only one guaranteed year left of Skubal in a Tigers uniform.

The Valdez signing in theory primarily does two things: It immediately makes the Tigers starting rotation one of the most formidable in the AL and signals to fans that the organization is serious about competing for the World Series in 2026.

The Tigers can also benefit from high-level pitching from Valdez without needing to commit to a long-term contract. The three-year deal Valdez signed with the Tigers could become a two-year deal if his opt-out is exercised after the 2027 season, turning a nine-figure deal into a much cheaper eight-figure deal for a Tigers front office with a reputation of avoiding big-money contracts. That means that even if the Valdez signing doesn't work out for Detroit (or if the Tigers need to reset without Skubal in 2027), he'll be off the books soon after and give the front office more room to work with.

Valdez hasn't commanded the same sort of attention recently as other AL stalwarts like Skubal, Boston's Garrett Crochet or New York's Gerrit Cole, never finishing higher than fifth in the AL Cy Young Award vote. But his steady success has made him one of MLB's most valuable pitchers over the last five seasons and fits very well with what the Tigers need.

Valdez's 18.3 FanGraphs WAR since 2021 is second among AL pitchers to Skubal, while his 3.20 ERA in the same span is third behind Skubal (2.96) and Yankees ace Gerrit Cole (3.15) among AL starters with at least 500 innings pitched in the same span. Valdez's 60 games of at least seven innings pitched since 2021 also leads all pitchers (Skubal, by comparison, has 30 in the same time frame), while his six complete games since 2021 is second in MLB behind Miami Marlins ace Sandy Alcantara's 10.

Valdez likely won't compete with Skubal for the top spot in the Tigers rotation, but he might be the best No. 2 pitcher in the AL heading into 2026 and a worthy ace should the Tigers miss Skubal for any reason in 2026 or 2027.

Need¬†to catch up on the news during your lunch break?¬†

You can reach Christian at cromo@freepress.com.

This article originally appeared on Detroit Free Press: Tarik Skubal arbitration, Tigers future after Framber Valdez signing

One of those stops included talkBOXING with host Simon Jordan. Wilder made it clear that he did not want to talk about past opponent, Tyson Fury, following [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Deontay Wilder is making the mandatory media rounds to promote his upcoming fight against Derek Chisora, scheduled for Sat., April 4, 2026 at The O2 Arena in London. One of those stops included talkBOXING with host Simon Jordan. Wilder made it clear that he did not want to talk about past opponent, Tyson Fury, following comments that ‚ÄúGypsy King‚Äù thwarted him by way of white supremacy.

Jordan ignored that directive and not surprisingly, Wilder had a meltdown.

Here‚Äôs the isolated clip (full video embedded above):

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt give a F*CK about that!‚Äù

Deontay Wilder EXPLODES and STORMS off talkBOXING with Simon Jordan and Derek Chisoraü§Øü§¨ 

You don‚Äôt want to miss tonight‚Äôs special! üëÄ #boxing @BronzeBomber @DerekWarChisora @Sjopinion10 pic.twitter.com/48DQFftyJx

‚Äî talkSPORT Boxing (@boxing_ts) February 4, 2026

Poison walked so that white supremacy could run.

‚ÄúI need this fight. I need Derek more than he needs me,‚Äù Wilder told reporters during a recent press conference (via ESPN). ‚ÄúI need to see where I am. I been broken down and rebuilt again. This is definitely a must-win for me. Not only a win, I need a devastating win, a knockout. That‚Äôs what we come to see. We got two beautiful heavyweights up there. You don‚Äôt know what to expect. He throws everything in the kitchen sink. You can have the toaster, the blender, everything else. He hits you in places you don‚Äôt want to be hit and he don‚Äôt care. I told Derek I want you to try and kill me. Because I need that and that‚Äôs what he‚Äôs going to do. It‚Äôs a special moment.‚Äù

Wilder has definitely been acting special over the last few years.

The 40 year-old ‚ÄúBronze Bomber‚Äù (44-4-1, 43 KOs) returned to the win column by¬†knocking around Tyrrell Anthony Herndon last summer in Wichita. As for Chisora, 42, he‚Äôs coming off three straight wins, having defeated Otto Wallin last year in Manchester to improve to 36-13 with 23 KOs.

title: U.S. Women Get Off To Impressive Start In Olympic Hockey With Historical First
description: The Americans dominated Czechia in their first match at the Milan-Cortina Games.
fullText:
MILAN ‚Äî Hayley Scamurra scored twice, and the United States opened the¬†Milan Cortina Games¬†women‚Äôs hockey tournament with a 5-1 win over Czechia on Thursday.

Alex Carpenter had a goal and assist, while captain Hilary Knight and Joy Dunne also scored for the Americans, who improved to 8-0 over the Czechs in international play. Aerin Frankel, making her Olympic debut in net, stopped 13 shots.

Laila Edwards had an assist while becoming the first Black female to represent America in hockey at the Olympics.

Barbora Jurickova scored Czechia‚Äôs lone goal. She was set up on a breakaway as she exited the penalty box to cut the Americans lead to 3-1 midway through the second period. Klara Peslarova finished with 37 saves in an outing Czechia was out-shot 31-9 through two periods.

The Czechs are making just their second Olympic appearance, and lost to the Americans in quarterfinal round of the 2022 Beijing Games. They are 0-6 against the U.S. in world championship play, including a 2-1 loss in the semifinals in April.

Like this article? Keep independent journalism alive. Support HuffPost.

The day‚Äôs only other scheduled Group A game between defending Olympic champion¬†Canada and Finland was postponed to Feb. 12. The Finns‚Äô roster was down to eight skaters and two goalies, with the remaining 13 players dealing with a stomach virus that hit the team on Tuesday.

title: Is France vs Ireland on TV? Kick-off time, channel and how to watch Six Nations clash
description: Everything you need to know ahead of the tournament opener
fullText:
France host Ireland in a potentially pivotal opening clash to the 2026 Six Nations.

The first fixture held on a Thursday in competition history brings together two sides that have split the last four titles, and both begin again with aspirations of lifting the trophy.

LIVE! Follow the Six Nations 2026 opener from the Stade de France

An injury-hit Ireland know their depth will be tested as they travel to Paris as part of a tough itinerary that also includes a trip to Twickenham in round three.

France, meanwhile, will know they cannot afford an early stumble if they are to defend their title.

Here‚Äôs everything you need to know.

France vs Ireland is due to kick off at 8.10pm GMT on Thursday 5 February at the Stade de France in Paris.

Viewers in the United Kingdom can watch the match live on ITV1, with coverage on the channel from 7.20pm GMT. A live stream will be available via ITVX.

Antoine Dupont returns to international action for the first time since tearing his ACL in this fixture last year, with the scrum half paired with Matthieu Jalibert in the absence of Romain Ntamack. Jalibert is one of four Bordeaux Begles backs selected, with Yoram Moefana and Nicolas Depoortere trusted in midfield.

Up front, Dorian Aldegheri is stationed at tighthead following the sad retirement of Uini Atonio, while it is a sizeable French back five even with Emmanuel Meafou withheld as part of a six forwards to two backs bench split.

The Prendergast brothers start a Test together for the first time, with younger brother Sam earning first crack in the No 10 shirt and elder brother Cian rewarded for good form for club Connacht and country this season in the back row. Tadhg Furlong has lost his race to be fit, leaving Thomas Clarkson to start on the tighthead, while Jeremy Loughman will face a tough test on the opposite side following a raft of loosehead injuries.

Jacob Stockdale, back to his best of late at Ulster, displaces James Lowe on the left wing as part of a back three that also includes Tommy O‚ÄôBrien and Jamie Osborne. Andy Farrell matches Fabien Galthie with a six/two split among his replacements.

France XV: 1 Jean-Baptiste Gros, 2 Julien Marchand, 3 Dorian Aldegheri; 4 Charles Ollivon, 5 Mickael Guillard; 6 Francois Cros, 7 Oscar Jegou, 8 Anthony Jelonch; 9 Antoine Dupont (capt.), 10 Matthieu Jalibert; 11 Louis Bielle-Biarrey, 12 Yoram Moefana, 13 Nicolas Depoortere, 14 Theo Attissogbe; 15 Thomas Ramos.

title: Remembering Christian Olsen's strength and spirit he showed us all
description: The Wayne Hills community reflects on Christian Olsen‚Äôs courage and legacy as loved ones share stories of his impact on and off the field.
fullText:
Christian Olsen waited his entire childhood to quarterback one football game for Wayne Hills High School, and nothing else mattered.

This was about family and sacrifice, doing whatever he could to deliver the one thing that had eluded his father, namesake and New Jersey coaching legend, and the program he built: a State championship.

In many ways, there was nothing to prove. The blue-chip prospect had already committed to attend the University of Notre Dame on a football scholarship, so his collegiate future was set.

If you thought a torn anterior cruciate ligament was going to stop a teenage Olsen from playing his senior season at Wayne Hills for a chance at that Holy Grail he and his teammates were chasing, then you just did not know Christian Olsen.

"I don't know where I'd be now if I didn't find a niche catching footballs from Christian Olsen," former Wayne Hills teammate and close friend Bill Monan said. "His toughness. His obsession to be great for his family, his teammates, his friends, and to live in that moment, for us as much as himself, there was no one like him."

Christian Olsen died Wednesday night at the age of 42 after a battle with brain cancer, a tragic and heartbreaking conclusion to a fight that embodied so much of what he meant to so many.

As former NFL star and FOX Sports analyst Greg Olsen wrote on social media Thursday morning of his older brother's passing: "This terrible disease took many things, but it could never take Chris' spirit for life."

To no one's surprise, Olsen fought the Glioblastoma with every ounce of his being. His parents, Chris and Sue, wound up moving from North Carolina, where they had relocated from New Jersey in retirement to be near Greg and his family, to Arkansas, where Christian and his wife Lindsay resided.

The Olsens rallied around their oldest son, and despite a bleak prognosis, Christian refused to quit.

"These past few weeks, people came from all over the country to Little Rock to share Chris stories," Greg wrote. "We laughed. We cried. We remembered a larger than life personality who made everyone feel his love. More importantly, he was able to feel the love and impact he made on countless people over his 42 years."

Monan and Brett Demmers made the trip to Arkansas to visit with Olsen last month, creating more lasting memories with "our quarterback," whose fight had taken an unimaginable toll on his daily living.

"Our senior year, he put his team first and he worked his ass off for us," Monan said. "He didn't want to let his father down, let his teammates down and he was going for that ring. Without Chris, we sure as hell weren't going to have a chance at that championship they finally got with Greg the year after us. Demmers and I were there with him a few weeks ago, and Chris had his Jersey Mike's, we just talked football and it was like old times."

Back then, Christian was seemingly destined for success. His right arm and sense of calm in the pocket brought countless scholarship offers, but what the 6-foot-4, 218-pounder wanted most was to be the varsity quarterback for Wayne HIlls and play with Greg, a dominant tight end and defensive end.

He could have opted for surgery after injuring his knee in the 2000 season opener at Indian Hills. Instead of sitting out, though, he wanted to be a Patriot, play with his friends and take a shot at finishing a quest they started years earlier at Wayne PAL.

As a senior, Christian threw for 1,864 yards and 24 touchdowns with just five interceptions, completing 56% of his passes (97-for-172) while playing with a bulky knee brace as a reminder of his resiliency.

In four of the 11 games he played, he did not attempt a pass in the second half.

His impact went beyond the numbers, of course. He wound up at the University of Virginia after transferring from Notre Dame and ultimately became a senior vice president in the logistics industry.

News of his passing Thursday morning created a ripple in the circle of friends Christian created from an early age on the playgrounds of North Jersey. Those who played for Coach Olsen at Wayne Hills a decade before were reaching out to Christian's teammates with messages such as: "The 91 team is thinking of your team today. Be strong like Chris."

When the Super Bowl was in New Jersey, we lost Jon "Goldy" Goldstein, a friend, a significant part of the Wayne Hills family as a longtime assistant coach and North Jersey sports fixture.

All these years later, again just days before the Super Bowl, we've lost Christian Olsen, and it hurts.

"Chris was a fighter through his entire journey, and he pretty much showed all of us, reminding us of the strength installed in us by playing for his father," friend Mike Fattal said. "It's been a rough day, I met Chris in the third grade on the basketball court, and we've been friends ever since."

Fattal relayed a story from New Year's Eve how he and another friend, A.J. Spicer, texted a photo of themselves to Christian, and the memories came flooding back, as they have over and over.

"We were always a team," Fattal said. "None of us wanted Chris to feel like he was fighting this battle alone."

I got a phone call from Chris Olsen out of the blue a few weeks ago. He was reaching out to let me know on a personal level what Christian had been going through, and how the family wanted all those who had gotten close to them through the years to be prepared for what his medical team had predicted.

There was a time in my life when co-workers joked that I was the fourth Olsen brother - Christian, Greg, Kevin and me - because of how much of my professional and personal life covering North Jersey sports in this capacity crossed paths with the family.

We spend countless hours covering teams and games, but in times like these, I'm always quick to remember that it's always about the people. The locker room banter. The sideline interactions.

I recall being in the hallway in Wayne Hills High School when Christian got the news that his ACL was torn. His season was supposed to be over - doctors just had to convince him that was the case, and he refused to accept that. One week later, he was back on the field.

Christian Olsen was one of the first star athletes I got the chance to know beyond the box scores. I traveled to South Bend and then Charlottesville to see Chris and Greg face off in college, and as Fattal shared Thursday morning, and it's true, with social media nowadays, you never really feel like you lose touch.

The last time I was in Christian's company, we were in Santa Clara, California, for Super Bowl 50 where Greg's Carolina Panthers played Peyton Manning and the Denver Broncos. We shared some laughs, reminiscing about the Wayne Hills days and how that Ramapo game in the State final his senior year should have continued after he threw a Hail Mary on the final moments for a touchdown.

"No way that was offensive pass interference," Christian yelled, and we all smiled. "We should've won that game."

All these years later, I wish I had a chance to share these memories with Christian one more time.

Rest easy, brother. Give Goldy a big hug for me.

This article originally appeared on NorthJersey.com: Christian Olsen remembered for courage by Wayne Hills football friends

title: In introductory presser, new Northwestern OC Chip Kelly sets expectations for a new era
description: Chip Kelly is ready to make a difference in Evanston.
fullText:
New Northwestern offensive coordinator Chip Kelly believes that the ‚ÄôCats are well-positioned to take a leap in a changing college football landscape.

‚ÄúAs I looked through everything, this was a situation that you get excited about,‚Äù said Kelly at his introductory press conference on Wednesday afternoon. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre excited about moving into a new stadium, excited about an up-and-coming team.‚Äù

Kelly, who was hired in early January, added that he did not have a strong previous relationship Northwestern, head coach David Braun or athletic director Mark Jackson. He said he made the decision to join Braun‚Äôs staff because he was ‚Äúintrigued‚Äù by Braun and Jackson‚Äôs vision for the program, as well as the opportunity to work with highly motivated student-athletes.

In describing his new offensive coordinator, Braun kept coming back to a single word: experience.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really easy to look at Chip‚Äôs experience and say, ‚ÄòAbsolutely, without a doubt, [he‚Äôs] the right person to be leading our offense,‚Äô‚Äù Braun said.

Kelly is one of the most decorated offensive minds of the last 20 years. In 12 seasons at Oregon and UCLA (10 as a head coach, two as offensive coordinator) Kelly‚Äôs offenses finished outside the top-20 in scoring just once. Recently, Kelly won a national championship as Ohio State‚Äôs offensive coordinator during the 2024-25 season, before a brief stint as the offensive coordinator for the Las Vegas Raiders.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm also excited about all the conversations Chip and I are having about program development,‚Äù said Braun. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd be silly to sit up here and and pretend like I have it all figured out‚Ä¶I know I have someone sitting to my left that has done it at an extremely high level in terms of coordinating offense, but also as a head coach.‚Äù

Kelly has spent his first month since being hired on the recruiting trail, first helping build Northwestern‚Äôs class of 16 transfers, and then making a series of visits to the school‚Äôs top targets in high school.

‚ÄúWe now have an opportunity to have conversations with young men that want to reach their fullest potential as a football player and [who] want to work with the best and the brightest people in the coaching space,‚Äù said Braun.

Kelly helped bring in new quarterbacks coach Jerry Neuheisel from UCLA, noting that he initially brought up Neuheisel‚Äôs name to Braun. Neuheisel was on Kelly‚Äôs staff for all six years that Kelly served as the Bruins‚Äô head coach. Neuheisel excelled as UCLA‚Äôs interim offensive coordinator in 2025, and he was carried off the field by his players after the Bruins‚Äô 42-37 upset victory over Penn State.

‚ÄúMyself and his dad, I think we‚Äôre [Neuheisel‚Äôs] two biggest fans,‚Äù said Kelly. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a rising star in this profession and I think he‚Äôll be a head coach really shortly.‚Äù

Braun is giddy to have both Kelly and Neuheisel on board.

‚ÄúI would argue that we‚Äôve got the best offensive staff in all of college football,‚Äù said Braun. ‚ÄúI feel like we‚Äôre really positioned to do some special things, not just in 2026 but for a long, long time.‚Äù

On Wednesday, Kelly acknowledged that he hasn‚Äôt gotten very far in his evaluations of the current roster, though he was incredibly complimentary of Northwestern running back Caleb Komolafe, calling him ‚Äúone tough sucker.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre studying film of what they‚Äôve done but just watching our guys at workouts,‚Äù Kelly said. ‚ÄúWe really won‚Äôt get a real good beat until we get on the field for spring ball, which will start sometime in the month of March.‚Äù

Near the end of the presser, Braun acknowledged the difficulties that lie ahead on Northwestern‚Äôs daunting 2026 schedule, which includes road matchups against Indiana, Oregon and Ohio State and 11 straight games without a bye week. Yet Northwestern‚Äôs leading man believes his team is up for the challenge.

‚ÄúThe Big Ten is the best football conference in the country, clearly‚Ä¶I embrace it with a smile on my face‚Äù Braun said. ‚ÄúBring on the competition. This is what we signed up for.‚Äù
